tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This question involves calculating the factor of safety using the von Mises failure criterion for a thin-walled cylinder. It requires calculating hoop stress and longitudinal stress, then applying the von Mises criterion, and finally calculating the factor of safety. It's a multi-step calculation but doesn't involve complex concepts.

answer_validation.reasoning: The factor of safety is the ratio of material failure stress (260 MPa) to the von Mises equivalent stress in the cylinder wall under pressure. For a thin-walled cylindrical pressure vessel, the principal stresses are hoop stress \sigma_h = pr/t and longitudinal stress \sigma_l = pr/(2t). The von Mises equivalent stress for a biaxial state (\sigma_3 \approx 0) is \sigma_{vm} = \sqrt{\sigma_h^2 + \sigma_l^2 - \sigma_h\sigma_l}. Substituting given values (p=0.5 MPa, r=150 mm, t=1 mm) yields \sigma_{vm}=64.95 MPa. Factor of safety = 260/64.95 \approx 4.0.

step_by_step: Step 1: Identify the given parameters. Internal diameter D=30 cm = 300 mm, so radius r=150 mm. Wall thickness t=1 mm. Internal pressure p=0.5 MPa. Material failure stress \sigma_{fail}=260 MPa.

Step 2: Recall stress formulas for thin-walled closed cylindrical pressure vessels. Hoop (circumferential) stress: \sigma_h = \frac{pr}{t}. Longitudinal (axial) stress: \sigma_l = \frac{pr}{2t}. Radial stress is negligible (\sigma_r \approx 0).

Step 3: Compute the principal stresses. \sigma_h = (0.5 \times 150) / 1 = 75 \text{ MPa}. \sigma_l = (0.5 \times 150) / (2 \times 1) = 37.5 \text{ MPa}. So \sigma_1 = \sigma_h = 75 \text{ MPa}, \sigma_2 = \sigma_l = 37.5 \text{ MPa}, \sigma_3 \approx 0.
Step 4: Apply the von Mises failure criterion for a biaxial stress state. The von Mises equivalent stress is \sigma_{vm} = \sqrt{\sigma_1^2 + \sigma_2^2 - \sigma_1\sigma_2}.
Step 6: Compute factor of safety (FoS). FoS = \frac{\sigma_{fail}}{\sigma_{vm}} = \frac{260}{64.95} \approx 4.002 \approx 4.0.

topic.name: Thin-Walled Pressure Vessels
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 4: Structures -> Stress and Strain -> Thin-walled pressure vessels

concepts.name: Hoop and Longitudinal Stresses in Cylinders

essential: Stress formulas for thin-walled cylindrical pressure vessels
Von Mises equivalent stress formula for biaxial stress state
helpful: Unit conversion (cm to mm, bar to MPa)

Main Concept: requires: Thin-walled pressure vessel stress analysis
enables: Design of pressure vessels for aerospace applications
enables: Assessment of structural safety margins

difficulty_factors: Requires recall of two distinct formulas (hoop/longitudinal stress and von Mises)
Unit consistency is critical (pressure in MPa, dimensions in mm)

textbook_references.author: Beer & Johnston
textbook_references.text_snippet: Stresses in thin-walled cylindrical pressure vessels: hoop stress and longitudinal stress formulas.

textbook_references.author: Boresi & Schmidt
textbook_references.text_snippet: Von Mises yield criterion for ductile materials under combined stress states.

video_references.topic_covered: Longitudinal stress derivation for thin cylinders

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Calculate principal stresses (hoop and longitudinal) → Compute von Mises equivalent stress → Divide failure stress by equivalent stress.
key_insights: For a thin-walled cylinder under internal pressure, radial stress is negligible, leading to a biaxial stress state.
Von Mises criterion is appropriate for ductile materials like metals used in gas cylinders.

formulas_principles.name: Hoop (Circumferential) Stress
formulas_principles.conditions: Thin-walled cylinder (t << r), internal pressure p.
formulas_principles.relevance: One of the two principal stresses in the cylinder wall.

formulas_principles.name: Longitudinal (Axial) Stress
formulas_principles.conditions: Thin-walled closed-end cylinder under internal pressure.
formulas_principles.relevance: The other principal stress in the cylinder wall.

formulas_principles.name: Von Mises Equivalent Stress (2D)
formulas_principles.conditions: Plane stress with \sigma_3 = 0; for ductile materials.
formulas_principles.relevance: The equivalent uniaxial stress to compare with material yield/failure stress.

formulas_principles.name: Factor of Safety
formulas_principles.conditions: Design context, where working stress is the calculated equivalent stress.

industry_examples: Gas cylinders for aerospace life support systems
Propellant tanks in rockets and missiles
specific_systems: High-pressure air bottles in fighter aircraft
Helium pressurant tanks in satellite propulsion systems
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Ensuring pressure vessels do not fail under operational loads is critical for safety. The factor of safety accounts for uncertainties in material properties, loads, and manufacturing defects.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using diameter instead of radius in stress formulas (e.g., using D in place of r).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Confusion between diameter and radius, or misreading the formula.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always note: stress formulas use radius r = D/2. Write r explicitly after converting diameter.
common_mistakes.consequence: Stress becomes half the correct value, leading to factor of safety twice as large.

common_mistakes.mistake: Incorrect unit conversion (e.g., pressure in bar not converted to MPa, or cm not converted to mm).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Rushing or not paying attention to units given (5 bar, 30 cm).
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Convert all parameters to consistent units (MPa for stress, mm for length) before calculation. 1 bar = 0.1 MPa, 1 cm = 10 mm.
common_mistakes.consequence: Wrong stress magnitude, leading to incorrect factor of safety.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the wrong failure criterion (e.g., Tresca maximum shear stress instead of von Mises).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Mixing up failure criteria for ductile materials.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember: Von Mises is most common for ductile aerospace metals (aluminum, steel). The problem explicitly states "von Mises failure criterion".
common_mistakes.consequence: Tresca gives \tau_{max}=(\sigma_1-\sigma_2)/2=18.75 MPa, equivalent stress=37.5 MPa, FoS=6.93 (option C), which is a trap.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting that the cylinder is closed-ended (using open-ended formulas).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Not reading carefully; open-ended cylinders have no longitudinal stress from pressure.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Note: 'Gas cylinder' implies closed ends. Longitudinal stress exists due to pressure on end caps.
common_mistakes.consequence: Missing \sigma_l, leading to wrong von Mises stress.

common_mistakes.mistake: Algebraic error in calculating von Mises stress (e.g., forgetting the cross term -\sigma_1\sigma_2).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Rushing through the square root calculation.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Write the formula clearly: \sigma_{vm}^2 = \sigma_1^2 + \sigma_2^2 - \sigma_1\sigma_2. Compute step by step.
common_mistakes.consequence: Overestimating equivalent stress, leading to lower FoS.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Hoop comes from pressure times radius over thickness (HoPRoT).
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Remembering the numerator for hoop stress.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Longitudinal stress is half the hoop stress for a thin-walled cylinder.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: Von Mises: Square of one plus square of two minus one times two, then square root.
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Von Mises equivalent stress for two principal stresses.

flashcards.front: What are the formulas for hoop and longitudinal stress in a thin-walled closed cylindrical pressure vessel?
flashcards.back: Hoop: $\sigma_h = \frac{pr}{t}$. Longitudinal: $\sigma_l = \frac{pr}{2t}$. (p=internal pressure, r=inner radius, t=wall thickness)

flashcards.front: What is the von Mises equivalent stress for a biaxial stress state (σ1, σ2, σ3=0)?
flashcards.back: $\sigma_{vm} = \sqrt{\sigma_1^2 + \sigma_2^2 - \sigma_1\sigma_2}$. It is used for ductile materials under combined stress.

flashcards.front: What common mistake leads to factor of safety ~6.9 instead of 4.0 in this problem?
flashcards.back: Using Tresca (max shear stress) criterion instead of von Mises. Tresca: $\tau_{max} = (\sigma_1-\sigma_2)/2 = 18.75$ MPa, equivalent stress = 37.5 MPa, FoS=260/37.5≈6.9 (option C).

flashcards.front: Given D=300mm, t=1mm, p=0.5MPa, compute hoop stress.
What is the factor of safety definition in stress terms?
flashcards.back: FoS = (Material failure stress) / (Maximum working stress or equivalent stress).

real_world_context.application: Design of high-pressure gas storage cylinders for aircraft.
real_world_context.industry_example: Oxygen cylinders in commercial aircraft for emergency passenger masks. They must be lightweight (thin-walled) but safe under pressure cycles.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: A low factor of safety risks catastrophic rupture; too high increases weight, reducing fuel efficiency.

real_world_context.industry_example: Liquid fuel tanks in launch vehicles experience internal pressure and axial loads. Von Mises criterion ensures yield does not occur.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Failure during flight would be catastrophic. Accurate FoS calculation is part of structural integrity verification.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Straightforward calculation if you recall the three key formulas (hoop, longitudinal, von Mises). Should take 2-3 minutes.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If unsure, note that option C (6.9) is likely from Tresca criterion, and option D (4.0) from von Mises. Von Mises is more common for ductile metals, so lean towards D.
exam_strategy.time_management: Budget 3 minutes. If stuck, compute stresses first, then guess between C and D.

search_keywords: difference between Tresca and von Mises

alternative_methods.name: Tresca (Maximum Shear Stress) Criterion
alternative_methods.description: Failure is predicted when maximum shear stress reaches the shear yield strength. For principal stresses σ1 and σ2 (σ3=0), τ_max = max(|σ1-σ2|/2, |σ1|/2, |σ2|/2). Equivalent stress = 2τ_max.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Conservative (safer) for ductile materials, simpler. But less accurate for some materials compared to von Mises.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When specified, or for quick conservative estimates.

alternative_methods.name: Maximum Principal Stress Criterion (Rankine)
alternative_methods.description: Failure when maximum principal stress exceeds tensile strength. For this problem, σ1=75 MPa, FoS=260/75=3.47.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Simple, used for brittle materials. Not suitable for ductile materials under multi-axial stress.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: For brittle materials like cast iron.

deeper_dive_topics: Cyclic pressure loading and fatigue failure
Finite element analysis of pressure vessels

syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Well-aligned with core syllabus topic 'Thin-walled pressure vessels' and 'Failure criteria'.

rag_quality.notes: RAG chunks provided stress formulas for thin-walled cylinders (hoop, longitudinal) and examples of combined stresses (Chunks 1, 3, 6). However, they did not cover the von Mises failure criterion explicitly. The RAG content was about maximum shear stress (Tresca) and design for stress/strain limits, which are related but not directly applicable. I relied on internal knowledge for von Mises formula and factor of safety calculation.

future_questions_potential: Change geometry to spherical vessel (stress formulas differ).
Include torsional load (adding shear stress component).
Ask for minimum thickness given FoS and pressure.
Use Tresca criterion instead of von Mises.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A gas cylinder (closed thin-walled cylindrical pressure vessel) of diameter 30cm and wall thickness 1mm is subjected to a design maximum internal pressure of 5bar (0.5MPa). The material used for manufacturing this cylinder has a failure stress of 260MPa. Assuming von Mises failure criterion, the factor of safety (with respect to maximum allowable stress) for this cylinder is
